update.description:
This pull request changes train_windows (in minibatch) to sort in reverse, such that the last index will not be greater than 9999.

This is to resolve [issue 75](#!/hoffmanlab/segway/issues/75/gmtk-does-not-allow-last-number-of).

content.raw: If you have `valid_gmtk_window_index` above, perhaps this should be called `valid_train_window` instead. There are an awful lot of `10000` references around and especially in variables names that should be avoided if necessary. They are essentially magic numbers. Ideally if it was super verbose it would be `less_than_max_gmtk_window_count` but these names are too long.
content.html: If you have valid_gmtk_window_index above, perhaps this should be called valid_train_window instead. There are an awful lot of 10000 references around and especially in variables names that should be avoided if necessary. They are essentially magic numbers. Ideally if it was super verbose it would be less_than_max_gmtk_window_count but these names are too long.

content.raw: "but doesn't both of those names (especially MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_COUNT) imply our total list of windows should not be greater than 9999" is completely true. We don't do it in our case specifically (or even check for it), but we do work around a bug where GMTK errenously doesn't properly detect it. `MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_COUNT` would be entirely correct.
content.html: "but doesn't both of those names (especially MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_COUNT) imply our total list of windows should not be greater than 9999" is completely true. We don't do it in our case specifically (or even check for it), but we do work around a bug where GMTK errenously doesn't properly detect it. MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_COUNT would be entirely correct.

content.raw: I think so actually. That sounds like it describes exactly what the constant is. You could keep "NUM" for the bases constant, but then it's more accurate to call the `WINDOW_NUM` constant `WINDOW_INDEX` which admittedly would turn it into `WINDOW_INDEX_INDEX`. I'm not sure what the best solution is. I think no matter what the naming is going to be weird because the data structure is weird.
content.html: I think so actually. That sounds like it describes exactly what the constant is. You could keep "NUM" for the bases constant, but then it's more accurate to call the WINDOW_NUM constant WINDOW_INDEX which admittedly would turn it into WINDOW_INDEX_INDEX. I'm not sure what the best solution is. I think no matter what the naming is going to be weird because the data structure is weird.

content.raw: I think I was trying to refer to the fact that train window tuples have the structure (window number, number of bases), ie (34, 500) for window number of 34, and a number of bases of 500. I am not sure what a better name would be--I'm not sure 'TRAIN_WINDOWS_BASES_INDEX' is clearer?
content.html: I think I was trying to refer to the fact that train window tuples have the structure (window number, number of bases), ie (34, 500) for window number of 34, and a number of bases of 500. I am not sure what a better name would be--I'm not sure 'TRAIN_WINDOWS_BASES_INDEX' is clearer?

content.raw:
This comprehension loops through the entire list instead of ending at the first instance where you find the window index you previous selected. Replace this with a for loop that breaks as soon as your match is found. Or replace with a more clever way to find it.

If you're going to be looping through all the windows perhaps you want to actually perform a comprehension where you filter out all the window indexes > 9999 and then randomly choose one of those windows. Whatever you think would make things clearer.
content.html:
This comprehension loops through the entire list instead of ending at the first instance where you find the window index you previous selected. Replace this with a for loop that breaks as soon as your match is found. Or replace with a more clever way to find it.

If you're going to be looping through all the windows perhaps you want to actually perform a comprehension where you filter out all the window indexes > 9999 and then randomly choose one of those windows. Whatever you think would make things clearer.

pullrequest.title: Change train_windows (in minibatch) to sort in reverse, such that the last index will not be greater than 9999

content.raw:
This is the maximum number of windows allowed for GMTK. "Number" is ambiguous in this named constant case because it could refer to an index or a count.

I'd suggest something simpler like `MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_COUNT` if you want to change the number to 10000
or `MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_RANGE_INDEX` if you want to change the number to 9999
content.html:
This is the maximum number of windows allowed for GMTK. "Number" is ambiguous in this named constant case because it could refer to an index or a count.

I'd suggest something simpler like MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_COUNT if you want to change the number to 10000 or MAX_GMTK_WINDOW_RANGE_INDEX if you want to change the number to 9999

content.raw: The random function chooses a number in the interval 0 to 1. [Uniform](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.random.uniform.html#numpy.random.uniform) is just picking a number between 0 to n according to a uniform distribution (that is, every number is equally likely). I think they are functionally the same.
content.html: The random function chooses a number in the interval 0 to 1. Uniform is just picking a number between 0 to n according to a uniform distribution (that is, every number is equally likely). I think they are functionally the same.

pullrequest.title: Change train_windows (in minibatch) to sort in reverse, such that the last index will not be greater than 9999

content.raw:
I think a better approach would be to explicitly have a case where the number of windows is greater than 10000 (0 to 9999). In this case randomly choose 1 window from the range [0:9999] inclusive, then choose the remaining windows randomly from the entire range.

Since this code depends on a future GMTK fix, make sure this special case is documented in the comments of the code referencing the issue.
content.html:
I think a better approach would be to explicitly have a case where the number of windows is greater than 10000 (0 to 9999). In this case randomly choose 1 window from the range [0:9999] inclusive, then choose the remaining windows randomly from the entire range.

Since this code depends on a future GMTK fix, make sure this special case is documented in the comments of the code referencing the issue.

pull_request.title: Change train_windows (in minibatch) to sort in reverse, such that the last index will not be greater than 9999

pullrequest.title: Change train_windows (in minibatch) to sort in reverse, such that the last index will not be greater than 9999

content.raw:
@ericr86 As discussed previously, resampling the random list of windows until there is at least one number less than 9999 is the simplest solution, I think.

Roughly the way to do this would be to check the lowest number in the reverse-sorted train windows, and if greater than 9999, then repeat this:

```
2078             train_window_indices_shuffled = choice(range(num_train_windows),
2079                                                    num_train_windows,
2080                                                    replace=False)
2081             train_windows = []
2082             cur_bases = 0
2083             total_bases = sum(
2084                 train_window[1] for train_window in train_windows_all
2085             )
2086 
2087             for train_window_index in train_window_indices_shuffled:
2088                 if (float(cur_bases) / total_bases) < self.minibatch_fraction:
2089                     train_windows.append(train_windows_all[train_window_index])
2090                     cur_bases += train_windows_all[train_window_index][1]
2091                 else:
2092                     break
2093 
```
and re-check, and repeat, until the smallest number is less than 9999. Is this something we would like to implement?

Thanks!
content.html:
@ericr86 As discussed previously, resampling the random list of windows until there is at least one number less than 9999 is the simplest solution, I think.

Roughly the way to do this would be to check the lowest number in the reverse-sorted train windows, and if greater than 9999, then repeat this:

2078             train_window_indices_shuffled = choice(range(num_train_windows),
2079                                                    num_train_windows,
2080                                                    replace=False)
2081             train_windows = []
2082             cur_bases = 0
2083             total_bases = sum(
2084                 train_window[1] for train_window in train_windows_all
2085             )
2086 
2087             for train_window_index in train_window_indices_shuffled:
2088                 if (float(cur_bases) / total_bases) < self.minibatch_fraction:
2089                     train_windows.append(train_windows_all[train_window_index])
2090                     cur_bases += train_windows_all[train_window_index][1]
2091                 else:
2092                     break
2093

and re-check, and repeat, until the smallest number is less than 9999. Is this something we would like to implement?

Thanks!

pullrequest.title: Change train_windows (in minibatch) to sort in reverse, such that the last index will not be greater than 9999

content.raw:
That was my original comment on here and I asked for your input on here (I'm not sure what happened to the comment). It seems like an unlikely case but not impossible to happen. It's more likely to occur depending on smaller split sequences and larger fractions for minibatch.

I'm not sure what the best solution is here. A trivial solution would be to resample the windows until your smallest index was less than 9999.
content.html:
That was my original comment on here and I asked for your input on here (I'm not sure what happened to the comment). It seems like an unlikely case but not impossible to happen. It's more likely to occur depending on smaller split sequences and larger fractions for minibatch.

I'm not sure what the best solution is here. A trivial solution would be to resample the windows until your smallest index was less than 9999.
